DataElement.preferredDefinition: The description of location or site within the body Biopsy was performed.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the named location of or within the body of a biopsy, removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body, executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: Named locations of, or within, the body.:Performed; carried out.

Concepts.definition: Named locations of or within the body.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A portion of the large intestine that includes the descending colon, sigmoid colon and rectum.

Concepts.definition: A portion of the large intestine that includes the sigmoid colon and rectum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the colon or rectum.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include lipoma and leiomyoma.  Representative examples of malignant neoplasms include carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.  Colorectal adenomas always exhibit epithelial dysplasia and are considered premalignant neoplasms._A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the colon or rectum.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include lipoma and leiomyoma.  Representative examples of malignant neoplasms include carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.  Colorectal adenomas always exhibit epithelial dysplasia and are considered premalignant neoplasms.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Neoplasm Polyp Greater Than Five Millimeter
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the colon or rectum.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include lipoma and leiomyoma.  Representative examples of malignant neoplasms include carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.  Colorectal adenomas always exhibit epithelial dysplasia and are considered premalignant neoplasms._A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations._A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status._A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one._A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the colon or rectum.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include lipoma and leiomyoma.  Representative examples of malignant neoplasms include carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.  Colorectal adenomas always exhibit epithelial dysplasia and are considered premalignant neoplasms.

A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations.
A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
